note.body:
OS: Fedora 41
Snapshot: 47.1 installed from Fedora packages (rpm)

Problem:
When taking photo using Snapshot with rear camera (with my hp elite g8), image shown on screen is flipped (horizontally) like seen on second image of my last post. On this image (captured with Spectale KDE), you can seen that LEFT and RIGHT are both flipped. But photo saved is not (first picture of my last post).

Expected behaviour:
As this camera is the rear camera, image on screen must not be flipped on screen (as it is for captured picture if a photo is taken).

How to reproduce:
Just launch snapshot: what is displayed on the screen for the rear camera is flipped horizontally.
@NicolasSellenet Please see my previous comment - thanks!

I have the same issue.

I have a HP Elite G8 computer with 2 cameras (front and rear). The rear camera shows an inverted image on the screen while the captured image is not.

You can see the problem on the screenshot and the captured image.

OS: Fedora 41

![Photo_du_2024-11-24_16-07-05.693566](/uploads/b59e53ca3b8c9a6b279c9ed5fad59d77/Photo_du_2024-11-24_16-07-05.693566.jpeg)

![Snapshot_rear_camera](/uploads/2e25383dc0347f62664b267289ef0617/Snapshot_rear_camera.jpg)

Same for Lenovo IdeaPad 3. I'm on Ubuntu 24.04 (Aperture 0.7.0, GStreamer 1.24.7, Pipewire 1.2.4, Gtk 4.16.3) and did:

```
flatpak install org.gnome.Snapshot
sudo apt install libcamera0.2
sudo apt install gstreamer1.0-libcamera
sudo apt install pipewire-libcamera
```

Output of `pw-dump | grep default.video.source` is empty.

Output of `RUST_LOG=snapshot=debug,aperture=debug flatpak run org.gnome.Snapshot` is:

```
2024-11-22T15:32:34.283869Z  INFO snapshot::application::imp: Snapshot (org.gnome.Snapshot)    
2024-11-22T15:32:34.283927Z  INFO snapshot::application::imp: Version: 47.1    
2024-11-22T15:32:34.283937Z  INFO snapshot::application::imp: Datadir: /app/share/snapshot    
2024-11-22T15:32:34.283947Z DEBUG snapshot::application::imp: Application::startup    
2024-11-22T15:32:34.450386Z DEBUG snapshot::application::imp: Application::activate    
2024-11-22T15:32:34.643580Z DEBUG aperture::viewfinder::imp: Setup recording    
2024-11-22T15:32:34.749808Z DEBUG snapshot::widgets::gallery: Done loading 0 pictures    
2024-11-22T15:32:34.784216Z DEBUG snapshot::widgets::gallery: Done loading 0 videos    
2024-11-22T15:32:34.875931Z DEBUG snapshot::widgets::camera: org.freedesktop.portal.Camera:IsCameraPresent: false    
2024-11-22T15:32:34.880053Z DEBUG aperture::device_provider: Starting device provider with file descriptor: 30    
2024-11-22T15:32:34.885256Z DEBUG snapshot::widgets::camera: Device provider started 
```

Camera works without problems in [Camera](https://gitlab.gnome.org/jwestman/camera), but not in [Decoder](https://gitlab.gnome.org/World/decoder/-/issues/90).
Please follow https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/snapshot/-/blob/main/TROUBLESHOOTING.md and submit any relevant information here.

As to the UX: From a user perspective, it is important to be able to help yourself on the spot: to switch horizontal and/or vertical, depending on what the camera actually shows. Two simple on/off buttons with "flip horizontally" and "flip vertically" are enough to help the user adjust to any setup they need, independent of what the camera shows initially. (Albeit this flexibility is mostly needed with external cameras I reckon.)

UPDATE: Found this post by the maintainer, which indicates this user option has been present before... https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/snapshot/-/merge_requests/39#note_1678428

I support introducing a way for users to switch the camera orientation. I am using a desktop/document camera. When I tested it some days ago it worked as intended (rigth/left correct). Today it does not and I can not use it for a hands-on training session as the app shows a mirrored picture. As it seems that the orientation does not remain the same consistently, the user needs an option to manually overrule.

UPDATE: I just realized that what I see on-screen is not what I get after taking a picture with Snapshot. On-screen the image is by default left-right-mirrored (=wrong). But when I take a picture, the orientation of the actual picture is correct?! THe same with the video feed. This is very irritating, given that https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/snapshot/-/merge_requests/39 was closed assuming the issue was resolved. (There is even another commenter at the bottom, having the same issue with an external camera.)
Fixed on https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/snapshot/-/merge_requests/330
Thanks for the report!

This path needs to be changed in `po/POTFILES.in` as well for string extraction to keep working.

Seen on https://l10n.gnome.org/module/snapshot/

note.body: Hi @drubo, thanks for reporting this. Currently this ticket does not describe the problem or topic well. If you have time and can still reproduce the situation, please follow the issue reporting guidelines linked from https://handbook.gnome.org/issues.html and add a more useful description to this ticket, including exact version information, package format (native deb/rpm, or Flatpak/Snap/etc), distribution information, clear and complete steps to reproduce (step by step, click by click), what you expect to happen, and what happens instead. target_title: Camera not found on HP Pavilion Plus

note.body:
Hi @gnagfloW, thanks for reporting this.
To receive help for code development support questions, configuration or preferences issues, or to answer "[How] Can I do...?" questions, please use https://discourse.gnome.org/ (or the support forum of your distribution, or the chat channel of the project if existing), as GNOME's ticket system is used for actionable feature requests and errors in the code of GNOME software.
I am closing this task as invalid. Thank you for your understanding!

I don't know whether using the video format is safe: there is the risk of confusing greyscale cameras with infrared ones.

However, do we really need to filter out IR cameras ? Is it plausible that someone really wants to see the output of the IR camera. What about just choosing as default the camera with higher priority ? At least in my case, the real camera has priority.session=1000, while the IR camera has priority.session=980.

In the example above the actual IR camera has
```
        video/x-raw(memory:SystemMemory) {
            format: (gchararray) "GRAY8",

```

it its caps while the real camera has
```
        image/jpeg(memory:SystemMemory) {
```

and
```
        video/x-raw(memory:SystemMemory) {
            format: (gchararray) "YUY2",
```


I don't know much about IR cameras - are there devices that support the later formats but not the former grey scale one? Otherwise I'd assume supported formats to be a better indicator than the name - and when in doubt rather filter too little than too much.
Yes, we filter cameras which have "IR" in their `node.nick` or `node.description`, as they are likely infrared cameras. I am not sure what a good solution would be.

target_title: aperture: make Viewfinders's GtkGraphicsOffload's allocation always match the video size

note.body:
That's what we were discussing - with the caveat that we were using `GtkGraphicsOffload:black-background` to get the same effect, because what matters for the offloading is the rendernode that gets offloaded, not the size of the widget.

And without offloading the black background, only the video image gets offloaded, which would get the effect you want, without having to relayout the widgetry.

target_title: aperture: make Viewfinders's GtkGraphicsOffload's allocation always match the video size

note.body: Maybe I wasn't clear in the issue description. The idea is to make the allocation of the GTKGraphicsOffload as small as possible so that the rounded corners my not be part of the video (when the edges are only black) and therefore the widget isn't clipped and offloading works.

target_title: aperture: make Viewfinders's GtkGraphicsOffload's allocation always match the video size

note.body: Right, the only benefit you get from this is avoiding the copy inside GTK that removes the corners, because you could do that while blitting the image in the compositor.

target_title: aperture: make Viewfinders's GtkGraphicsOffload's allocation always match the video size

note.body:
> Dunno how hard that is going to be in the end - it feels like it'd be easier to implement rounded corners in a Wayland protocol and Mutter?

Main problem with such protocols is that it's effectively SSD - and well, that's not an easy topic. Especially when it's questionable whether there's a big benefit here. If you use Snapshot or some video player in floating mode, Mutter (and most other compositors) currently isn't able to use HW-planes anyway.

> You could try implementing it on the GTK side, but this is going to be work.

Yeah...I'm not convinced that it's really worth it investing much into this in the given state. We already have the most import paths covered, crucially the fullscreen and maximized ones, the later being used by default on phones.

target_title: aperture: make Viewfinders's GtkGraphicsOffload's allocation always match the video size

note.body:
You could try implementing it on the GTK side, but this is going to be work.

Because instead of 3 states (not offloaded, offloaded above, offloaded behind) you'll have 5 states (not offloaded, offloaded above, offloaded above without background, offloaded behind, offloaded behind without background) and that means the renderer needs to track 2^5=32 potential transitions properly instead of 2^3=8 like it does now. And you need to communicate those 5 states to the renderers and make sure they handle them properly (ie you need to sometimes draw black with a hole). And then there's also the question of how to hook that into the debugging framework so people like you guys know what's actually going on.

Dunno how hard that is going to be in the end - it feels like it'd be easier to implement rounded corners in a Wayland protocol and Mutter?

target_title: aperture: make Viewfinders's GtkGraphicsOffload's allocation always match the video size

note.body:
> You could set `GtkGraphicsOffload:black-background` only on maximized/fullscreen when there are no round corners, that'd get you a bit better results maybe?

Yep, I guess that should work and would be sensible. So much that I wonder if GTK4 could do it automatically in order to avoid having to do this in any app using the black background - or would that be too annoying on the GTK side?

target_title: aperture: make Viewfinders's GtkGraphicsOffload's allocation always match the video size

note.body:
No. As long as there are rounded corners, offloading can't happen.  
We'd need a way to cut off corners from a `wl_surface` and that doesn't exist.

You could set `GtkGraphicsOffload:black-background` only on maximized/fullscreen when there are no round corners, that'd get you a bit better results maybe?

target_title: aperture: make Viewfinders's GtkGraphicsOffload's allocation always match the video size

note.body: Yeah, this is a general issue around the optimized black background on one hand and rounded corners on the other. It similarly applies to Showtime etc. and has already been discussed quite a bit. @otte, did you have any new ideas regarding this topic?

target_title: aperture: Use GtkGraphicsOffload to draw black background

note.body:
There are two reasons why offloading isn't used one is this and a second one is https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/snapshot/-/issues/242

You can see it for yourself with `GDK_DEBUG=offload`

target_title: aperture: Use GtkGraphicsOffload to draw black background

note.body: I guess we need to bump gtk version, for this.

note.body: @kha84: Most likely you're running Pipewire 1.0 or a 1.2 < 1.2.4. In that case https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/pipewire/pipewire/-/merge_requests/2145 should help.

If your issue is marked as a duplicate of this issue, please read https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/snapshot/-/blob/main/TROUBLESHOOTING.md. Most importantly try updating pipewire & wireplumber and restart their respective services.

Mobian/trixie pinephone rear camera is black and does not take photos: snapshot 47.0.1-5

note.body: Linux 6.12 is not needed; `sunxi64_6.6.56` from https://repo.mobian-project.org/pool/main/l/linux-6.6-sunxi64 solves the rear camera bug. This should arrive in Mobian/trixie on the time scale of a few weeks or months.

target_title: Mobian/trixie pinephone rear camera is black and does not take photos: snapshot 47.0.1-5

note.body:
Applying the pmOS patch to `libcamera 0.3.2-1` and installing the patched binaries (where `-filterHWISP` is added by me in the package version name):
````
dpkg -i libcamera0.3_0.3.2-1.1-filterHWISP_arm64.deb libcamera-ipa_0.3.2-1.1-filterHWISP_arm64.deb gstreamer1.0-libcamera_0.3.2-1.1-fil
````
does _not_ solve the bug in `Mobian/trixie` with linux `6.6.23+sunxi64-1`.

However, the bug appears to have been solved in a different way in Mobian: it seems that handling it in the kernel is the most sustainable option. The [Mobian wiki section on PinePhone cameras](https://wiki.debian.org/InstallingDebianOn/PINE64/PinePhone#Cameras) has [been updated](https://wiki.debian.org/InstallingDebianOn/PINE64/PinePhone?action=diff&rev2=34&rev1=33) to now state that `gnome-snapshot` is only expected to work on `linux 6.12`, not `linux 6.6`, and this is on the [Mobian staging release](https://packages.mobian.org).

So this is clearly a distro issue, please move it there.

target_title: Mobian/trixie pinephone rear camera is black and does not take photos: snapshot 47.0.1-5
Mobian/trixie pinephone rear camera is black and does not take photos: snapshot 47.0.1-5

note.body:
Experiments with the [front and back camera kill switches](https://wiki.pine64.org/wiki/PinePhone#Privacy_switch_configuration), with `snapshot 47.0.1-5 with 2cf4643b` cherry-picked.

 1. Set front camera switch to _off_ and leave the **rear** camera _on_; restart `pipewire`; `pw-dump |grep "video\.source"`. 
   * First try: This gave similar behaviour to above - dark central screen image and photo cannot be taken - but the double-camera-icon button is absent and there appears to be no way to use the front camera.
 2. Set **front** camera switch to _on_; set rear camera switch to _off_; restart `pipewire`; `pw-dump |grep "video\.source"`.
   * Several tries: Similar to above - snapshot appears to only detect the front camera. However, `pw-dump |grep "video\.source"` gives:
````
      { "subject": 0, "key": "default.video.source", "type": "Spa:String:JSON", "value": { "name": "libcamera_input._base_i2c-csi_rear-camera_4c" } }
````
 3. Set **rear** camera switch to _on_; set front camera switch to _off_; `pw-dump |grep "video\.source"` does not find any matching lines. This was tried several times in a row with the same result.
 4. Set **both** kill switches to _on_. Behaviour fully returned to the main bug behaviour described above, with the double-camera-icon button being present, the front camera image showing normally, and the rear camera image being black.

Interpretations/comments: 
* The `pw-dump` statement that the rear camera is the default.video.source when the rear camera has been switched off and `pipewire` has been restarted suggests that in this case, the front camera is incorrectly named by pipewire as the "rear" camera. 
* The behaviour of snapshot with the rear camera switch _off_ is inconsistent in this series of tests.

target_title: Mobian/trixie pinephone rear camera is black and does not take photos: snapshot 47.0.1-5

note.body:
https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/snapshot/-/issues/236 suggests that wireplumber 0.5.7 or 2cf4643b might fix this. Wireplumber 0.5.7 is [not yet available in Debian](https://tracker.debian.org/pkg/wireplumber).

To test the hypothesis that 2cf4643b fixes this, I built snapshot-47.0.1-5 with 2cf4643b cherry-picked using the standard Debian tools. This did not solve the bug: the behaviour appears to be identical to what I reported above for snapshot-47.0.1-5 provided by Debian/trixie.

target_title: Does not work with Mobian on PinePhone

note.body:
Right now, `gnome-snapshot 47.0.1-2` works for me for the front camera on `Mobian/trixie` (i.e. `Debian/Mobian testing`) on `PinePhone v1.2b` for photos and for video (though the audio recording is blank). I recorded photos and videos with the front camera, and viewed and played them successfully on a different machine. So it seems to that your bug is rather an issue for Mobian/Debian than for upstream.

I don't see `gnome-snapshot` at https://packages.mobian.org , so it doesn't seem to be maintained as a Mobian-specific package. So it seems like a wider Debian-mobile issue.

My guess is that in Mobian/bookworm, you should expect [megapixels](https://tracker.debian.org/pkg/megapixels) to work out-of-the-box for still photos, but I would be very surprised if `gnome-snapshot` would be considered to be supported in Mobian/bookworm, since it [only arrived in Debian in Jan 2024](https://tracker.debian.org/pkg/gnome-snapshot/news), which was seven months _after_ `bookworm` became `Debian/stable`. My guess is that backporting the full range of dependencies to bookworm would be a nightmare. I would recommend that you look through https://wiki.debian.org/Mobian and https://wiki.debian.org/Teams/DebianOnMobile and ask on #debian-mobile irc/matrix if backporting `gnome-snapshot` to bookworm is likely.

note.body: Oh, this is actually already correct from the Pipewire side and the issue is indeed in Snapshot. This should have been fixed on `main` by https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/snapshot/-/commit/2cf4643b0abc1a238f8f38c3eb8250a347ccb10d but that wasn't backported yet to `47`. Could you try nightly (quickest way probably the [nightly flatpak](https://welcome.gnome.org/app/Snapshot/#installing-a-nightly-build)) to confirm it's fixed there?

target_title: Switching output should not warn if only one camera exists

note.body:
Cameras in Snapshot are managed by Wireplumber (like audio devices). On most setups this should already work, however you might have a unusual device in which case things *might* get fixed in https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/pipewire/wireplumber/-/merge_requests/674 / Wireplumber 0.5.7

Mind posting the output of `gst-device-monitor-1.0 Video/Source` to be sure?

target_title: Switching output should not warn if only one camera exists

note.body: Please follow https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/snapshot/-/blob/main/TROUBLESHOOTING.md and submit any relevant information here.
